content.raw:
about :

~~~
EXPECT_EQ(_type, msgs::ConvertGeometryType(msgs::ConvertGeometryType(_type)));
~~~

somehow I am a little more pedantic about comparing with hardcoded value more often to be sure the values are correct. This is to avoid situations where `EXPECT_EQ(a, b)` is true but `a` and `b` got turned into `NULL`s or `0`s somewhere in the code. You mind if I leave the existing comparisons in place in addition to your one?
content.html:
about :

EXPECT_EQ(_type, msgs::ConvertGeometryType(msgs::ConvertGeometryType(_type)));

somehow I am a little more pedantic about comparing with hardcoded value more often to be sure the values are correct. This is to avoid situations where EXPECT_EQ(a, b) is true but a and b got turned into NULLs or 0s somewhere in the code. You mind if I leave the existing comparisons in place in addition to your one?

pull_request.title: Update Visual's get/set functions and add unit tests

pullrequest.title: Update Visual's get/set functions and add unit tests

content.raw: yes agreed. I added more descriptions to the doxygen comment in 7ceefb5. We could subclass if there's a strong reason to do so. I think our Visual class is like a node in a scene tree where it can have child visuals as well as other objects attached to it (very similar to ogre). We could set the specular of a model visual that overrides (or adds) to the child visual's specular value. `GetSpecular` would then return the value local to the model visual itself. But you are correct that the SDF element in this case would be meaningless. We can think about avoid setting the sdf element if it doesn't have a geometry element for example. Note that there is nothing to limit us from attach an object (e.g. a box) to a model visual on the client side for visualization purposes, and `SetSpecular` would change the specular of the object and `GetSpecular` would actually mean something.
content.html: yes agreed. I added more descriptions to the doxygen comment in 7ceefb5. We could subclass if there's a strong reason to do so. I think our Visual class is like a node in a scene tree where it can have child visuals as well as other objects attached to it (very similar to ogre). We could set the specular of a model visual that overrides (or adds) to the child visual's specular value. GetSpecular would then return the value local to the model visual itself. But you are correct that the SDF element in this case would be meaningless. We can think about avoid setting the sdf element if it doesn't have a geometry element for example. Note that there is nothing to limit us from attach an object (e.g. a box) to a model visual on the client side for visualization purposes, and SetSpecular would change the specular of the object and GetSpecular would actually mean something.

pullrequest.title: Update Visual's get/set functions and add unit tests

content.raw: +1. [This inheritance diagram](http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/gazebo/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1rendering_1_1Visual.html) shows that Visual has many subclasses, many of which do not have SDF associated with them. It's not the fault of this PR, however, since it doesn't add the SDF member, just the accessor for it. A SetSDF function here would be far more problematic. Maybe there even needs to be a distinction between the C++ interface for the SDF Visual element and the class that acts as an interface to the rendering library...
content.html: +1. This inheritance diagram shows that Visual has many subclasses, many of which do not have SDF associated with them. It's not the fault of this PR, however, since it doesn't add the SDF member, just the accessor for it. A SetSDF function here would be far more problematic. Maybe there even needs to be a distinction between the C++ interface for the SDF Visual element and the class that acts as an interface to the rendering library...

pull_request.title: Update Visual's get/set functions and add unit tests

pullrequest.title: Update Visual's get/set functions and add unit tests

content.raw:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but since `Visual` is a pretty general class, here we could be getting a <model> element, <link> element or <visual> element, right? Come to think of it, there are several subclasses of Visual which don't have SDF counterparts, things like `JointVisual`, for which creating and updating all these sdf elements would be unnecessary.

I guess in the future we could subclass `Visual` into things like `ModelVisual` and `LinkVisual` and implement their specific functions which refer to SDF. Because as of now, I don't think it makes much sense to call, for example, `GetSpecular` on a visual that represents a model, because this visual basically exists to hold the link visuals and has no material of its own, so we might get some meaningless value from this function. Does it make sense?

I guess what I want to say for now is that maybe at least in the documentation we could make it clear that several SDF elements are represented by `Visual`. Something like "Get the SDF element represented by this visual. It could be, for example, a model, a link or a visual element."...

I hope I didn't say a bunch of crazy stuff :]
content.html:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but since Visual is a pretty general class, here we could be getting a <model> element, <link> element or <visual> element, right? Come to think of it, there are several subclasses of Visual which don't have SDF counterparts, things like JointVisual, for which creating and updating all these sdf elements would be unnecessary.

I guess in the future we could subclass Visual into things like ModelVisual and LinkVisual and implement their specific functions which refer to SDF. Because as of now, I don't think it makes much sense to call, for example, GetSpecular on a visual that represents a model, because this visual basically exists to hold the link visuals and has no material of its own, so we might get some meaningless value from this function. Does it make sense?

I guess what I want to say for now is that maybe at least in the documentation we could make it clear that several SDF elements are represented by Visual. Something like "Get the SDF element represented by this visual. It could be, for example, a model, a link or a visual element."...

I hope I didn't say a bunch of crazy stuff :]
